standard_metadata.standard_description: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.

question.content: It takes Ebru $13$ minutes to bike to school.  If she walks, it takes her twice as long. Ebru leaves for school at $7{:}15$.  **What time will Ebru get to school if she walks?**   ${:}$

hints.content: It takes Ebru $\blueD{13}$ minutes to bike to school, and she walks there in $\greenD{\text{twice}}$ that time.  $\blueD{13}\text{ min} \times\greenD2= \purpleD{26}\text{ min}$  It takes Ebru $\purpleD{26}$ minutes to walk to school.

Ebru is leaving at $7{:}\maroonD{15}$ and takes $\purpleD{26}$ minutes to walk to school.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {7{:}15} +{} &\maroonD{15}\text{ minutes} = 7{:}30\\\\ {7{:}30} +{} &\purpleD{11}\text{ minutes} = \blueD{7{:}41} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 7 o'clock to 7:45 with 7:15 and 7:30 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A pink arrow labeled plus 15 points to the right along the number line from 7:15 to 7:30. A purple arrow labeled plus 11 points to the right along the number line from 7:30 to the eleventh unlabeled tick mark after 7:30.

hints.content: Ebru will get to school at $7{:}41$.

question.content: It takes Bob $36$ minutes to walk to school.  If he runs, it takes him half that time. Bob leaves for school at $7{:}27$.  **What time will Bob get to school if he runs?**   :

hints.content: It takes Bob $\blueD{36}$ minutes to walk to school. He can run there in $\maroonD{\text{half}}$ of that time.  $\blueD{36}\text{ minutes} \times\maroonD{\dfrac12} = \greenD{18}\text{ minutes}$  It takes Bob $\greenD{18}$ minutes to run to school.

Bob is leaving at $7{:}\purpleD{27}$ and takes $\greenD{18}$ minutes to run to school.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {7{:}27} +{} &\purpleD{3}\text{ minutes} = 7{:}30\\\\ {7{:}30} +{} &\greenD{15}\text{ minutes} = \blueD{7{:}45} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 7:15 to 8 o'clock with 7:30 and 7:45 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A purple arrow labeled plus 3 points to the right along the number line from the twelfth unlabeled tick mark after 7:15 to 7:30. A green arrow labeled plus 15 points to the right along the number line from 7:30 to 7:45.

hints.content: Bob will get to school at $7{:}{45}$.

question.content: It takes Natasha $33$ minutes to walk to the pool from her house.  If she rides her bike, it takes her $\dfrac13$ of that time.   **Natasha leaves her house for the pool at $3{:}12$. If she is riding her bike, what time will she arrive?**   :

hints.content: Biking to the pool takes $\maroonD{\dfrac13}$ as long as walking does. Since walking takes $\blueD{33}$ minutes:  $\blueD{33}\text{ minutes} \times\maroonD{\dfrac13} = \greenD{11}\text{ minutes}$

Natasha leaves at $3{:}\purpleD{12}$ to bike to the pool, and it takes her $\greenD{11}$ minutes to get there.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {3{:}12} +{} &\purpleD{3}\text{ minutes} = 3{:}15\\\\ {3{:}15} +{} &\greenD{8}\text{ minutes} = \blueD{3{:}23} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 3 o'clock to 3:30 with 3:15 tick mark labeled at the halfway point. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A purple arrow labeled plus 3 points to the right along the number line from the twelfth unlabeled tick mark after 3 o'clock to 3:15. A green arrow labeled plus 8 points to the right along the number line from 3:15 to the eighth unlabeled tick mark after 3:15.

hints.content: Natasha will arrive at the pool at $3{:}23$.

question.content: It takes Chris $30$ minutes to walk to work.  If he drives, it takes him $\dfrac13$ of that time.   **What is the latest time that Chris can leave to drive to work and arrive by $8{:}00$?**   :

hints.content: Driving to work takes $\maroonD{\dfrac13}$ as long as walking does. Since walking takes $\blueD{30}$ minutes:  $\blueD{30}\text{ minutes} \times\maroonD{\dfrac13} = \purpleD{10}\text{ minutes}$  It takes Chris $\purpleD{10}$ minutes to drive to work.
Chris needs to arrive at work by  $8{:}00$, and it takes him $\purpleD{10}$ minutes to drive there.  [[☃ image 1]]  $8{:}00 - \purpleD{10}\text{ minutes} = 7{:}50$

images.alt: A number line extends from 7:45 to 8:15 with 8 o'clock tick mark labeled at the halfway point. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A purple arrow labeled minus 10 points to the left along the number line from 8 o'clock to the fifth unlabeled tick mark after 7:45.

hints.content: Chris has to leave by $7{:}50$ to get to work on time.

question.content: Wilma loves to run.  Wilma ran for $1$ hour and $15$ minutes $3$ days this week.  **How many minutes did Wilma run in total?**       minutes

hints.content: First, let's convert $1$ hour and $\maroonD{15}$ minutes.  $1\text{ hour} = \blueD{60}\text{ minutes}$    $\begin{align} 1\text{ hour } \maroonD{15}\text{ minutes} &= \blueD{60}\text{ minutes} + \maroonD{15}\text{ minutes}\\\\ & = \purpleD{75}\text{ minutes} \end{align}$
Wilma runs $\purpleD{75}$ minutes on $\greenD3$ days.  Let's multiply to find the total.  $\purpleD{75} \times \greenD3= \text{?}$
Wilma ran for a total of $225$ minutes.

question.content: Ajay is allowed to watch $2$ hours of television on Saturdays.  Each episode of his favorite show lasts $30$ minutes.  **How many episodes may he watch?**     episodes

hints.content: First, let's convert his allowed time to minutes.  $1\text{ hour} = \blueD{60}\text{ minutes}$  $\begin{align} \purpleD2\text{ hours} &= \purpleD2 \times \blueD{60}\text{ minutes} \\\\ &= \greenD{120}\text{ minutes} \end{align}$

Next, we can divide the $\greenD{120}$ minutes into pieces that are each $\maroonD{30}$ minutes long.  How many $\maroonD{30}$ minute shows does it take to make $\greenD{120}$ minutes?  $\greenD{120}\text{ minutes} \div \maroonD{30}\text{ minutes} = \text{?}$
Ajay can watch $4$ episodes of his favorite show.

question.content: Ronald is making pot roast for dinner.  He has been cooking the pot roast for $1$ hour and $5$ minutes.  The pot roast needs to cook for $40$ more minutes.  **How many minutes does the pot roast cook in total?**   minutes

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ hour $\greenD{5}$ minutes.  $1$ hour $= \blueD{60}$ minutes  $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ hour }\greenD{5}\text{ minutes} &=\blueD{60}\text{ minutes}+\greenD{5}\text{ minutes}\\\\ &=65\text{ minutes} \end{align}$
The pot roast has been cooking for $65$ minutes, and it still needs to cook for $40$ minutes.  $65$ minutes $+$ $40$ minutes $=\text{?}$ minutes  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 110 with tick marks by tens. A bracket above 0 to 65 is labeled 65 and a bracket above 65 to 105 is labeled 40.

hints.content: The pot roast needs to cook for a total  of $105$ minutes.

question.content: Duane is making a casserole for dinner.  He has been cooking the casserole for $1$ hour and $48$ minutes.  The casserole needs to cook for $47$ more minutes.  **How many minutes does the casserole cook in total?**   minutes

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ hour $\greenD{48}$ minutes.  $1$ hour $= \blueD{60}$ minutes  $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ hour }\greenD{48}\text{ minutes} &=\blueD{60}\text{ minutes}+\greenD{48}\text{ minutes}\\\\ &=108\text{ minutes}\end{align}$
The casserole has been cooking for $108$ minutes, and it still needs to cook for $47$ minutes.  $108 + 47 =\text{?}$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 160 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 108 is labeled 108 and a bracket above 108 to 155 is labeled 47.

hints.content: The casserole needs to cook for a total of $155$ minutes.

question.content: Alma wants to swim one lap in the pool as fast as her friend Blanca, who can swim one lap in $1$ minute and $23$ seconds. Alma started swimming her lap in the pool $57$ seconds ago.   **How much time does Alma have left to finish her lap if she wants to tie Blanca's time?**   *Write the answer in seconds.*   seconds

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ minute $\greenD{23}$ seconds.    $1$ minute $= \blueD{60}$ seconds    $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ minute }\greenD{23}\text{ seconds} &=\blueD{60}\text{ seconds}+\greenD{23}\text{ seconds} \\\\ &=83\text{ seconds}\end{align}$
Alma has been swimming for $57$ seconds, and she has to finish in $83$ seconds.    $57 + \text{?} = 83$   $83 - 57 = \text{?}$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 85 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 57 is labeled 57 and a bracket above 57 to 83 is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: Alma has $26$ seconds to finish her lap.

question.content: Shelbi wants to run one lap around the track as fast as her friend Annabelle, who can run one lap in $1$ minute and $10$ seconds. Shelbi started running her lap around the track $47$ seconds ago.   **How much time does Shelbi have left to finish her lap if she wants to tie Annabelle's time?**   *Write the answer in seconds.*   seconds

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ minute $\greenD{10}$ seconds.    $1$ minute $= \blueD{60}$ seconds    $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ minute }\greenD{10}\text{ seconds} &=\blueD{60}\text{ seconds}+\greenD{10}\text{ seconds} \\\\ &=70\text{ seconds}\end{align}$
Shelbi has been running for $47$ seconds, and she has to finish in $70$ seconds.    $47 + \text{?} = 70$   $70 - 47 = \text{?}$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 70 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 47 is labeled 47 and a bracket above 47 to 70 is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: Shelbi has $23$ seconds to finish her lap.

question.content: Walter is making curry for dinner.  The recipe says that the curry should cook for $1$ hour and $25$ minutes.  He has been cooking the curry for $59$ minutes.    **According to the recipe, how much longer does Walter need to cook the curry?**   *Write the answer in minutes.*   minutes

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ hour and $\greenD{25}$ minutes.    $1$ hour $= \blueD{60}$ minutes  $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ hour }\greenD{25}\text{ minutes} &=\blueD{60}\text{ minutes}+\greenD{25}\text{ minutes} \\\\ &=85\text{ minutes}\end{align}$
So the curry needs to cook for $85$ minutes, and it has been cooking for $59$ minutes.    $59 + \text{?} = 85$   $85 - 59 = \text{?}$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 85 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 59 is labeled 59 and a bracket above 59 to 85 is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: Walter has to continue cooking the curry for $26$ minutes.

question.content: Martin is taking a test at school.  His teacher gave him $1$ hour and $15$ minutes to complete the test.  He has been taking the test for $54$ minutes.    **How many minutes does Martin have left to finish the test?**   minutes

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD1$ hour and $\greenD{15}$ minutes.   $1$ hour $= \blueD{60}$ minutes  $\begin{align}  \blueD1\text{ hour }\greenD{15}\text{ minutes} &=\blueD{60}\text{ minutes}+\greenD{15}\text{ minutes} \\\\ &=75\text{ minutes}\end{align}$
Martin has $75$ minutes to take the test, and he has been taking the test for $54$ minutes.    $54 + \text{?} = 75$   $75 - 54= \text{?}$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 75 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 54 is labeled 54 and a bracket above 54 to 75 is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: Martin has $21$ minutes left to finish the test.

question.content: Amanda is cooking a turkey for dinner.  The recipe says that the turkey should cook for $1\dfrac12$ hours.  She has been cooking the turkey for $25$ minutes.    **According to the recipe, how many more minutes does the turkey need to cook?**   minutes

hints.content: First we need to convert $\blueD{1}\greenD{\dfrac12}$ hours.  $1$ hour $= \blueD{60}$ minutes  $\begin{align}  \blueD1\greenD{\dfrac12}\text{ hour }&=\blueD{60}\text{ minutes}+\greenD{30}\text{ minutes}\\\\ &=90\text{ minutes}\end{align}$
The turkey needs to cook for $90$ minutes, and it has been cooking for $25$ minutes.    $25 + \text{?} = 90$   $90 - 25= \text{?}$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 0 to 90 with tick marks by fives. A bracket above 0 to 25 is labeled 25 and a bracket above 25 to 90 is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: Amanda has to cook the turkey for $65$ minutes more.

question.content: It takes Carrie $58$ minutes to get home.   **If Carrie leaves for home at $1{:}32$, what time will she arrive?**   :

hints.content: We start at $1{:}32$ when Carrie leaves her home.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 1:30 to 2:30 with 1:45, 2 o'clock, and 2:15 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A red point is plotted on the second unlabeled tick mark after 1:30.

hints.content: To determine what time Carrie will arrive, we go **right** ${58}$ minutes from $1{:}32$.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {1{:}32} +{} &\maroonD{8}\text{ minutes} = 1{:}40\\\\ {1{:}40} +{} &\purpleD{20}\text{ minutes} = {2{:}00}\\\\ 2{:}00 +{} &\blueD{30}\text{ minutes} = {2{:}30} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 1:30 to 2:30 with 1:45, 2 o'clock, and 2:15 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A pink arrow labeled plus 8 points to the right along the number line from the second unlabeled tick mark after 1:30 to the tenth unlabeled tick mark after 1:30. A purple arrow labeled plus 20 points to the right along the number line from the tenth unlabeled tick mark after 1:30 to 2 o'clock. A blue arrow labeled plus 30 points to the right along the number line from 2 o'clock to 2:30.

hints.content: Carrie will arrive home at $2{:}30$.

question.content: Bart's drive to the airport takes $23$ minutes. He needs to arrive at the airport by a quarter to $6$.  **If Bart needs to arrive by a quarter before $6$, what is the latest time Bart can leave for the airport?**   :

hints.content: Bart has to be at the airport by a quarter before $6$. What time is a quarter before $6$?  $1$ hour $= 60$ minutes    $\begin{align} 1\text{ quarter hour} &= 60 \times \dfrac{1}{4} \\\\ &=\dfrac{60\times1}{4}\\\\ &=60\div4\\\\ &= 15\text{ minutes} \end{align}$  A quarter before $6$ is $5{:}45$.
So, we start at $5{:}45$ when Bart needs to arrive at the airport.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 5 o'clock to 6 o'clock with 5:15, 5:30, and 5:45 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A red point is plotted on the 5:45 tick mark.

hints.content: To determine what time Bart will need to leave, we go **left** ${23}$ minutes from $5{:}45$.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {5{:}45} -{} &\maroonD{15}\text{ minutes} = 5{:}30\\\\ {5{:}30} -{} &\purpleD{5}\text{ minutes} = {5{:}25}\\\\ 5{:}25 -{} &\blueD{3}\text{ minutes} = {5{:}22} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 5 o'clock to 6 o'clock with 5:15, 5:30, and 5:45 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A pink arrow labeled minus 15 points to the left along the number line from 5:45 to 5:30. A purple arrow labeled minus 5 points to the left along the number line from 5:30 to the tenth unlabeled tick mark after 5:15. A blue arrow labeled minus 3 points to the left along the number line from the tenth unlabeled tick mark after 5:15 to the seventh unlabeled tick mark after 5:15.

hints.content: Bart must leave by $5{:}22$ in order to get to the airport by a quarter before $6$.

question.content: Max's trip home takes $32$ minutes.  He needs to arrive home by half past $5$.  **What is the latest time Max can leave to be home?**   :

hints.content: Max has to be home half past $5$.  What time is half past $5$?  $1$ hour $= 60$ minutes    $\begin{align} \dfrac12\text{ hour} &= 60 \times \dfrac{1}{2} \\\\ &=\dfrac{60\times1}{2}\\\\ &=60\div2\\\\ &= 30\text{ minutes} \end{align}$  Half past $5$ is $5{:}30$.
So, we start at $5{:}30$ when Max needs to arrive home.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 4:45 to 5:45 with 5 o'clock, 5:15, and 5:30 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A red point is plotted on the 5:30 tick mark.

hints.content: To determine what time Max needs to leave, we go **left** ${32}$ minutes from $5{:}30$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {5{:}30} -{} &\maroonD{30}\text{ minutes} = 5{:}00\\\\ 5{:}00 -{} &\blueD{2}\text{ minutes} = {4{:}58} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 4:45 to 5:45 with 5 o'clock, 5:15, and 5:30 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A pink arrow labeled minus 30 points to the left along the number line from 5:30 to 5 o'clock. A blue arrow labeled minus 2 points to the left along the number line from 5 o'clock to the thirteenth unlabeled tick mark after 4:45.

hints.content: Max must leave by $4{:}58$ in order to get home by half past $5$.

question.content: Mr. Potter's class will take a test for $1\dfrac12$ hours.  They need to finish by half past $11$ to get to lunch on time.  **What is the latest time the class can start the test to get to lunch on time?**   :

hints.content: Mr. Potter's class needs to be done at half past $11$.  What time is half past $11$?  $1$ hour $= 60$ minutes    $\begin{align} \dfrac12\text{ hour} &= 60 \times \dfrac{1}{2} \\\\ &=\dfrac{60\times1}{2}\\\\ &=60\div2\\\\ &= 30\text{ minutes} \end{align}$  Half past $11$ is $11{:}30$.
So, we start at $11{:}30$ when Mr. Potter's class needs to go to lunch.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line extends from 10:45 to 11:45 with 11 o'clock, 11:15, and 11:30 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A red point is plotted on the 11:30 tick mark.

hints.content: To determine what time the class needs to start the test, we go **left** ${1}$ hour and $30$ minutes from $11{:}30$.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} {11{:}30} -{} &\maroonD{1}\text{ hour} = 10{:}30\\\\ 10{:}30 -{} &\blueD{30}\text{ minutes} = {10{:}00} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line extends from 10:45 to 11:45 with 11 o'clock, 11:15, and 11:30 tick marks labeled at 15 minute intervals. Tick marks are shown at 1 minute intervals. A pink arrow labeled minus 1 hour points to the left along the number line from 11:30 to 10:30. A blue arrow labeled minus 30 minutes points to the left along the number line from 10:30 to 10 o'clock.

hints.content: Mr. Potter's class should start the test no later than $10{:}00$.
